awd_titl_txt: Research Initiation Award: Regulation of Gene Expression by the CD44-ICD Signaling Pathway
awd_abstract_narration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities-Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) Research Initiation Awards (RIAs) provide support to STEM junior faculty at HBCUs who are starting to build a research program, as well as for mid-career faculty who may have returned to the faculty ranks after holding an administrative post or who need to redirect and rebuild a research program. Faculty members may pursue research at their home institution, at an NSF-funded Center, at a research intensive institution or at a national laboratory. The RIA projects are expected to help further the faculty member's research capability and effectiveness, to improve research and teaching at his or her home institution, and to involve undergraduate students in research experiences. With support from the National Science Foundation, Delaware State University (DSU) will conduct research aimed at addressing a major gap in knowledge in the regulation of gene expression. This project will be used to enhance teaching and learning at DSU with a focus on mentoring and training freshman and sophomore students. The proposed research experiences will provide access for undergraduate STEM students, mainly from underrepresented minority groups, to participate in advanced cellular, molecular and biophysical investigations at DSU. The early involvement of STEM students in active research will increase the retention and graduation rates in STEM as well as increase the production of highly qualified students for graduate school and the STEM global workforce.

The goal of the proposed study is to understand the mechanisms by which CD44 regulates gene expression in the cell. The specific aims of this project are to: 1) characterize protein-protein interactions between CD44 intracytoplasmic domain (ICD) and transcription factors Runx2 and/or p53 in cells and to assess the CD44-mediated functional expression of matrix metalloproteinase 9 gene (MMP-9) in the chick embryo model; and 2) map a CD44-ICD minimal binding domain in the protein-protein interactions with p53 and/or Runx2 and to assess its potential use as a small molecule modulator of the CD44 signaling pathway. This proposal combines in vitro and in vivo cellular, molecular and biophysical experimental approaches to investigate how protein-protein and protein-DNA interactions between the CD44-ICD and transcription factors and gene promoters, respectively, regulate gene expression. Detecting details at the molecular level of this gene regulatory mechanism will provide a potential approach to modulate the expression of such genes and their effects on cell phenotypes and thus behavior in cellular physiology and developmental biology.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This Research Initiation Award (RIA) project produced new experimental data related to a mechanism in which the cell membrane protein CD44 send signals into the nucleus to regulate the expression of genes in cells and thus cellular behavior. I proposed that such mechanism involves a small segment of the CD44 protein that is cleaved in the inside of the cell membrane. This segment is named  the CD44 intracytoplasmic domain (CD44-ICD) and it comes from the end of the protein which faces towards the inside of the cell. Our experiments have validated that the CD44-ICD interacts with other proteins (particularly proteins involved in transcription, also known as transcription factors) in the nucleus to carry out the regulation of gene expression. In addition, we have discovered a new interaction of the CD44-ICD with the same transcription factors but in the cytoplasm (outside the nucleus). This unexpected finding has prompted us to consider potential mechanisms that control the movement of the CD44-ICD from or to the nucleus by the interacting transcription factors. As part of the efforts to uncover the mechanistic details of the CD44-ICD-mediated cell signaling, we created mutants of the CD44-ICD protein segment in which sections were removed to analyze potential effects on the signals that controls the expression of genes. We found that such mutants can indeed alter gene expression in the cell. This finding provides more validating information on this regulatory mechanism of gene expression and a potential approach to modulate such signal and the accompanying changes of cell behavior.

 

This RIA project also allowed me to mentor and train, directly and indirectly, many students (mostly underrepresented minority students, URM), including High School, undergraduates, and graduate students. Originally, I proposed to train 3 undergraduates for 2 years and then 3 more for a year. However, the turnover of students (including graduating, moving to other institutions and in part the effect of the pandemic) was larger than I expected which provided me the opportunity to train a lot more than 6 students. Leveraging resources from other funding agencies and programs (HHMI, NIH INBRE, NIH U-RISE etc.) I mentored and trained, 1 High Schooler, 37 undergraduates and 7 graduate students. Of these, 27 undergraduates already graduated and 5 of the graduate students already defended their thesis successfully and continued to secure academic, industry and government jobs in STEM fields. This accomplishment in training the next generation of scientist, mostly from URM backgrounds, is expected to have an impact on inclusion, diversity and equity of our future STEM scientists and physicians.

 


Last Modified: 09/29/2023
Modified by: Karl E Miletti
